awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Autonomous Integration of EMR Information for Patient-Centric Open API Access
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a tool for autonomous capture, translation, and integration of proprietary clinical information from Electronic Medical records into a standard public format. The project addresses ongoing healthcare regulations such as the PPACA which require doctors to provide patient access to medical data through electronic means, as well as efficiently share with other providers. Due to the nature of existing Electronic Medical Record systems, data sharing is difficult and discouraged. . Further an Open API will be provided to allow authorized third parties to access such data. Research will focus on data capture, parsing, and machine learning techniques to ensure accuracy and performance. It is expected that multiple methods will be evaluated and at least one method will be implemented in a prototype system.  

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will enhance the capability of patients to control their own medical data, its sharing, who has access, and analysis by hospitals and research institutions for ongoing medical research. By placing control of the patient?s data in the hands of the patient, they can choose to keep or share any or all medical data to any provider, or for research purposes. The rapid extraction and integration of data from multiple sources and provision of an open API will remove medical data from the control of vendors with no economic incentive to ensure data sharing. By allowing a single platform for integration, interrogation, and sharing, research and other software platforms can be built on top of the API to enhance medical research, patient awareness, and physician awareness of all data sources, including hospitals, other doctors, third party applications, and the growing use of ?Quantified Self? measurement devices.  Significant increases in efficiency for provider use and reduced expenditures on custom coded EMR solutions are anticipated, eliminating the requirement for millions of dollars of consulting, and improved patient care through efficient use of doctor time and provision of relevant information.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Gliimpse is transforming healthcare through creation of a single, simple to use, easily accessible portal, where patients can finally access all their data from multiple sources. A single simple view presents data in an easy to understand manner, reducing confusion and uncertainty. This places control of the information in the hands of the patient for the first time. It allows the data to be shared with others such as relatives or doctors, fully under the control of the patient, meeting HIPAA and all security/privacy requirements. Through more effective healthcare information access, patients can gain insights into their treatments, and doctors can provide more detailed, effective, and cost efficient healthcare, and with anonymous data donation, patients can now safely give their data to research and advance the state of healthcare across the country.


Some images of the Gliimpse application and data available are attached.


Gliimpse's goal is to create a plug-and-play software tool to automate the capture, translation and integration of silo’d Electronic Medical Record (EMR) and portal data, into standardized, portable and curated file formats, transforming how patients engage with their personal health data. This not only meets the reporting and patient access requirements of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) but finally place control of health data in the hands of its owner - the patient. This allows patients not only to see their data from all sources in a 'single pane of glass' view, but choose the 'who, when, and what' of data sharing. Integration will also allow medical practioners and researchers to finally be able to gain efficiencies from their patient's data, helping to reduce costs of the $3 Trillion per year industry. 

Major outcomes and findings were:

1) Data extraction from Electronic Medical Records was initially archived through installation of 'printer drivers' on database systems, then dramatically enhanced via a 'Portal driver' do download information from medical web portals such as those from doctors, hospitals, pharmacies, and labs. This expands Gliimpse's capabilities to around 150,000,000 patients in the USA. 

2) Initial methods of extracting and organizing data via machine learning proved too complex for effective use. Simplified methods based on ongoing discussions with clinicians as to most relevant data, and use of current messaging standards resulted in a more effective, faster, and useful outcome. 

An end-to-end demonstration of data extraction, standardization, integration and display of healthcare data was performed successfully.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/29/2014
Modified by: Anil Sethi

Images (1 of )
  • An example of Gliimpse providing data to a mobile phone app.
